awd_titl_txt: Molecular Simulation Study of Rock-Water-Oil Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Oil recovery is an important world-wide enterprise with significant social, economic, and environmental impacts. When oil is extracted from an underground reservoir, only about 10% is removed via pressure and pumping.  Secondary and tertiary recovery methods are used to extract the remainder of the oil, and these involve physical and chemical stimulation of the oil well, respectively.  One such stimulation technique is the injection of a high salinity brine or surfactants (soaps) into the subsurface.  These chemicals not only displace the oil, but also alter the chemical interaction, or "wetting", of the oil with subsurface rock. Decreasing the chemical interaction by which the rock "holds onto" the oil facilitates oil recovery.  How wetting behavior evolves with changing reservoir conditions is not fully understood. This project uses computational tools to probe molecular interactions that dictate the wetting behavior and to elucidate the connection between the larger environment of the reservoir with the microscopic details of the rock, oil and brine/surfactant. 

This research project uses molecular simulations to probe wetting phenomena, including molecular interactions at the brine-oil and brine-mineral interface. These interfacial properties are known to affect capillary pressure, which is the key determinant in the wettability of porous rock. The project also quantifies the extent to which acids, bases, and asphaltenes adsorb onto the rock surface, and the potential of this adsorption to change both rock surface chemistry and rock-brine-oil interfacial interactions. The extent to which wettability evolves with temperature, surface concentration, and the chemical identity of the surface will elucidate how wettability evolves with changing reservoir conditions.  The role of surfactants in altering interfacial interactions is also being explored. As this system is quite complex, the project goal is to develop quantitative relationships that connect macroscopic properties to microscopic structure. These relationships will enable the rational design of safe, efficient, and environmentally friendly solutions for oil extraction. Students are being trained on surface thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, and computer simulations. Outreach activities to area high schools are educating students about the impact of engineering studies on society and everyday life.

por.por_cntn:
Petroleum is a naturally occurring liquid that serves as the raw material for many consumer products.  The extraction of oil is completed by tapping wells in underground reservoirs and subsequently recovering the oil through a series of steps that progressively escalate in cost.  When the well is first tapped, oil naturally flows to the surface due to a relatively high underground pressure.  During this first phase, 5 to 15% of the original oil content of the well is extracted.  Eventually, the underground pressure decreases and oil production diminishes.  A second recovery phase is then initiated in which the pressure within the well is artificially increased via fluid injection (e.g. water, natural gas, carbon dioxide) or the application of pumps.  This phase typically brings the total amount of oil extracted to 30 to 50% of the original oil content of the well.  During a third recovery phase various "enhanced oil recovery" (EOR) methods are used to extract up to 50% of the remaining oil.  These methods facilitate recovery by increasing the mobility of the oil (e.g. reduced capillary pressure).

Oil reservoirs consist of porous rock (minerals such as silica) in contact with aqueous (water) and oil phases. The wetting behavior of the rock-water-oil system influences all three phases of the oil recovery process.  The relative preference that the rock exhibits for the oil and water phases has a significant impact on the extent to which oil can be recovered from the well.  From an oil recovery perspective, one prefers a "water-wet" scenario in which water preferentially wets the mineral surface and oil is displaced from the interior of pores.  Oil is the more mobile phase and is driven to the surface as pressure is applied to the well.  As such, many strategies are designed to drive the wetting properties towards "water-wet" conditions. Development of such strategies is greatly enhanced by a fundamental understanding of the factors that influence the wetting properties of rock-water-oil systems.

The goal of this project was to develop and implement computational strategies for probing outstanding questions related to the interfacial behavior of rock-water-oil systems. There were two primary scientific objectives of this study.  The first was to develop tools that facilitate the study of rock-water-oil systems via molecular simulation.  The second objective was to implement these tools to obtain a better understanding of the factors that control wettability in rock-water-oil systems.

We first completed a study related to the impact of carboxylic acids on the wetting behavior of a silica-water-octane system. We tracked the change in the octane-water interfacial tension and the contact angle of a water droplet on a silica substrate in a mother octane fluid over a range of acetic acid activities. We observed that acetic acid has a strong tendency to adsorb at the octane-water interface, resulting in a reduction in the octane-water interfacial tension. The response of the contact angle was sensitive to the temperature and the hydrophilicity of the silica substrate. The results provide insight regarding the impact that acidic components within crude oil have on reservoir wetting conditions.

We next completed a study related to the impact of substrate polarity on the wetting behavior of a silica-water-octane system. Our results illustrated an anomalous trend in the contact angle of water. For relatively hydrophobic surfaces, the system behaved as is expected, with increases in substrate polarity resulting in a decrease in the contact angle. However, at a sufficiently high substrate polarity, the value of the contact angle reached a minimum, with further increases in polarity leading to an increase in the contact angle. We showed that a monolayer-thick precursor film surrounds the droplet at sufficiently high substrate polarity. We linked the evolution of these macroscopic properties to the manner in which water organizes at the silica surface. The analysis revealed that water molecules reside within the hollows of the silica surface at sufficiently high substrate polarity. As the polarity increases, the interfacial water molecules progressively adopt a more planar structure and limit the number of hydrogen bonds that they form with water in subsequent interfacial layers. This evolution of the interfacial water structure leads to an effective weakening of the water-substrate interaction and corresponding increase in the water contact angle. The results demonstrate the significant impact substrate molecular structure can have on wetting behavior.

As the project unfolded, we recognized an opportunity to extend our modeling strategy to polymer membrane systems. In collaboration with Prof. Haiqing Lin's group (University at Buffalo), we investigated the impact of zwitterionic tethers on the anti-fouling characteristics of polymer membranes. Simulation results showed that the grafting of zwitterionic polymer tethers significantly increases the surface strength of a base polymer membrane. In contrast, opposite effects on membrane hydrophilicity were observed from the grafting of non-zwitterionic tethers to the base membrane.
